heading.title: PART 37 TIME TO PAY AND PAYMENT BY INSTALMENTS [rr 37.1–37.7]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 37 TIME TO PAY AND PAYMENT BY INSTALMENTS [rr 37.1–37.7]

leg:heading.title: TIME TO PAY AND PAYMENT BY INSTALMENTS [rr 37.1–37.7]

row.entry: These Rules govern the procedure that applies to the making of instalment orders by the registrar or the court pursuant to an agreement between the parties or an application by the judgment debtor.
This rule provides that Pt 37 does not apply to the payment of fines under the Fines Act 1996.

entry.emph: Effect of application for instalment order — Rule 37.5

row.entry: This Rule sets out the effect of an instalment order application on the execution of a judgment.

entry.emph: Variation, recission or determination of instalment order — Rules 37.6–37.7

row.entry: These Rules govern the procedure for the variation or recission of instalment order on the grounds of improvement of the judgment debtor's financial circumstances and set out the effect of non-compliance of a judgment debtor with an instalment order.
This Part applies to all courts in Sch 1 of the CPA, except the Industrial Court and the Industrial Relations Commission: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
The Part is based on the former DCR Pt 31A and LCR Pt 27.
Compliance with instalment order — failure of ‥ [r 37.7]

p.text: This Part does not apply to a fine in relation to which enforcement action is being taken under Division 4 of Part 4 of the Fines Act 1996.
The Fines Act 1996 has its own regime for the payment of fines by instalments.
[r 37.1 insrt Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[12], effective 8 August 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 37.1A] r 37.1A Instalment order made pursuant to agreement between judgment creditor and judgment debtor (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 2; LCR Part 27, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Instalment order made pursuant to agreement between judgment creditor and judgment debtor (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 2; LCR Part 27, rule 2)

p.text: A judgment creditor and judgment debtor may enter into an agreement (an instalment agreement):
specifying the amount agreed by them to be owing under the judgment debt, and
specifying by what instalments, payable at what times, that amount is to be paid.
An instalment agreement may be entered into whether or not an instalment order is already in force in respect of the judgment debt.
An instalment agreement may be entered into on behalf of a judgment creditor or judgment debtor by his or her solicitor or barrister.

An instalment agreement has no effect for the purposes of this rule unless the signature of each person executing it (other than a solicitor or barrister) is witnessed by a registrar or other officer of the court or by a solicitor or barrister.
As soon as practicable after an instalment agreement is filed, the court must make an instalment order that gives effect to the agreement.
[r 37.1A renum Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[12], effective 8 August 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 37.2] r 37.2 Application for instalment order by judgment debtor (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 2; LCR Part 27, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Application for instalment order by judgment debtor (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 2; LCR Part 27, rule 2)

p.text: A judgment debtor may apply to the court for an instalment order with respect to the amount owing under the judgment debt.
Such an application:
may be made whether or not some other instalment order is in force in relation to the judgment debt, and
must be supported by an affidavit as to the judgment debtor’s financial circumstances, and
must be dealt with as soon as practicable after it is made.
An application under this rule:
except as provided by paragraph (b), is to be dealt with by the registrar under rule 37.3, or
if it is made during a hearing before the court, is to be dealt with by the court under rule 37.4.

Notice of motion of an application under this rule does not have to be filed or served if the application is made during the hearing at which the judgment debtor is being examined pursuant to an order for examination.
[subr (5) rep Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[6], effective 6 July 2009]
The approved forms are Form 46 : Notice of motion to pay by instalments — Individual and Form 47 : Notice of motion to pay by instalments — Corporation.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 37.3] r 37.3 Instalment order made by registrar

p.text: The registrar may deal with an application for an instalment order:
by making an instalment order in relation to the amount owing under the judgment debt, or
by making an order refusing the aplication.
[subr (1) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[43], effective 15 August 2005]
As soon as practicable after making an instalment order under this rule, the registrar:
must give notice of the order to the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor, and
must also give to the judgment creditor a copy of the affidavit referred to in rule 37.2(2)(b).
Either party may file an objection to an order made under subrule (1)(a) or (b) at any time within 14 days after the order is made.

Form 48 is the approved form for an Instalment order and notice. The approved form for an order refusing an instalment application and notice is Form 49 . Form 50 is the approved form for a Notice of motion — objection to instalment order or order refusing instalment application.

In cases dealt with by a registrar, the judgment creditor’s application for an instalment order is advanced and dealt with on an ex parte basis, with notice of any instalment order made being given to the judgment creditor after the event, accompanied by the affidavit on which the judgment debtor relied in pursuing the application for the order: Tatlers.com.au Pty Ltd v Davis [2006] NSWSC 1055; BC200608082 at [20] (order for payment of judgment debt by instalments made after service of demand).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 37.4] r 37.4 Instalment order made by court (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 2; LCR Part 27, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Instalment order made by court (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 2; LCR Part 27, rule 2)

p.text: This rule applies if the court is dealing with:
an application for an instalment order pursuant to rule 37.2(3)(b), or
an objection against an order made under rule 37.3(1)(a) or (b).
On receiving the application or objection, the court:
must set the matter down for hearing, and
must give notice of the time, date and place of the hearing to the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor, and
if it has not already been done, must also give to the judgment creditor a copy of the affidavit referred to in rule 37.2(2)(b).
The court may determine an application for an instalment order, or an objection against an order refusing such an application:
by making an instalment order in relation to the amount owing under the judgment debt, or
by dismissing the application.
The court may determine an objection against the making of an instalment order:
by varying or rescinding the instalment order, or
by dismissing the objection.

As soon as practicable after making its determination, the court must give notice of the determination and (if it makes or varies an instalment order) of the terms of the order or the order as varied, to the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor.
Legislation cited in [37.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 37.3.
(QLD) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 1999 r 869.

An application to rescind or vary an instalment order under UCPR r 37.3 , is a hearing de novo and is not in the nature of an appeal from the order of the Registrar: Chint Australasia Pty Ltd v Cosmoluce Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1054; BC200808762 at [5] (citing Cahill v Howe [1986] VR 630 at 631 ; Lewis v Leslie [2001] VSC 110; BC200102031 at [22] ). Ordinarily a judgment creditor is entitled to payment. If the judgment debt relates to significant commercial litigation, particular circumstances would have to apply before it would be appropriate to make, or continue, an instalment order in relation to such a judgment debt: Chint Australasia Pty Ltd v Cosmoluce Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1054; BC200808762 at [15] (instalment order allowing debtor to pay a judgment for $5M plus in instalments over a period of almost two years — order rescinded): contrast Hellier Capital Pty Ltd v Albarran [2009] NSWSC 403; BC200903976 at [18], [23] (judgment debtor with illiquid net assets — likelihood of bankruptcy and consequential loss professional livelihood — instalment order allowing payment of judgment debt exceeding $1.6m over 4 years). The rules do not indicate the matters that a court should take into account deciding to make an instalment order or in deciding to rescind or vary one (cf Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 1999 (Qld) r 869 where specified circumstances must be taken into account eg, judgment debtor’s employment, means, assets and liabilities). An instalment order is unlikely to be made if:

the judgment debtor’s means are sufficient to enable payment of the judgment debt immediately and in full: Leondaris v KGB Design & Construction Pty Ltd [1998] FCA 1354; BC9805692 ; Chint Australasia Pty Ltd v Cosmoluce Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1054; BC200808762 ;
it would be futile because the judgment debtor could not meet the obligations under it: Cahill v Howe [1986] VR 630 at 631 ; and

the amount proposed to be paid would not enable some reduction to be made in the amount of the judgment debt (taking into account interest on the judgment debt): Hellier Capital Pty Ltd v Albarran [2009] NSWSC 403; BC200903976 at [11], [22] ; Red Lea Chickens Pty Ltd v Tansey (NSWCA, Kirby, Clarke, Sheller JJ, CA 40368 of 1993, 17 July 1995, unreported, BC9505123).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 37.4A] r 37.4A Payment of instalments under instalment order

leg:heading.title: Payment of instalments under instalment order

p.text: Unless the court for special reasons orders otherwise, the judgment debtor must pay the amounts under an instalment order to the judgment creditor.
This rule does not apply to money recovered on behalf of a person under legal incapacity.
The payment of money recovered on behalf of a person under legal incapacity is regulated by section 77 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005.
[r 37.4A insrt Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[11], effective 8 August 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 37.5] r 37.5 Stay of execution pending determination of application for instalment order

leg:heading.title: Stay of execution pending determination of application for instalment order

p.text: Execution of the judgment to which an application for an instalment order relates is stayed:
from the time the application is made until the time the application is determined, and

if the application is refused by an order under rule 37.3(1)(b) and an objection against the order is filed under rule 37.3(3), from the time the objection is filed until the time the objection is determined.
Subrule (1) does not apply if the applicant has previously made an application under this rule with respect to the same judgment debt.
See also section 107(2) of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 which provides for stay of execution of the judgment while an instalment order is in force.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 37.6] r 37.6 Variation or rescission of instalment order on proof of improvement in judgment debtor’s financial circumstances (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 3; LCR Part 27, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Variation or rescission of instalment order on proof of improvement in judgment debtor’s financial circumstances (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 3; LCR Part 27, rule 3)

p.text: A judgment creditor may apply to the court for the variation or rescission of an instalment order.

Such an application must be supported by an affidavit as to the judgment debtor’s financial circumstances, indicating the extent to which they appear to have improved since the instalment order was made.
On receiving the application, the registrar:
must set the matter down for hearing, and
must give notice of the time, date and place of the hearing to the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor.
The court may determine the application:
by varying or rescinding the instalment order to which it relates, or
by dismissing the application.
As soon as practicable after making its determination, the court must give notice of the determination and, if it varies the instalment order, of the terms of the order as varied:
to the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor, and
if the determination relates to an instalment order to which a garnishee order is subject, to the garnishee.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 37.7] r 37.7 Effect of instalment order on judgment debt (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 3; LCR Part 27, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Effect of instalment order on judgment debt (cf DCR Part 31A, rule 3; LCR Part 27, rule 3)

p.text: Subject to any agreement referred to in rule 37.1A , an instalment order ceases to have effect if the judgment debtor fails to comply with the order.
[r 37.7 am Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[13], effective 8 August 2008]
